Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54019-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
July 2020 
 
 
 
 
Fostering Expanded Regional Electricity and Gas 
Interconnection and Trade under the CAREC 
Energy Strategy 2030 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

and Financial Management Department

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the implementation of 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Energy Strategy 2030 in achieving its 
long-term vision of a reliable, sustainable, resilient, and reformed regional energy market by 
2030.1 The TA aims to improve regional energy connectivity, scale up investments, and achieve 
greater sustainability and inclusiveness in CAREC’s energy sector. To achieve these goals, the 
TA will (i) undertake preparatory works for the establishment of a new regional transmission 
cooperation association, (ii) strengthen government capacity to carry out market reforms and 
attract investors, (iii) establish a financing vehicle for green energy projects and foster consumer 
awareness of energy efficiency, and (iv) establish a women in energy program to increase 
women’s participation in the energy sector.2 These activities are directly linked to the strategic 
priorities of the CAREC Energy Strategy 2030 and represent the first subset of actions to be 
implemented as part of the strategy. 
 
2.  The TA is anchored in the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 Operational 
Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–2024.3 It supports the 
plan’s overall vision of sustained cooperation among countries as a foundation for advancing 
trade, investment, and the provision of regional public goods; and closely aligns with its strategic 
operational  priorities  1  (greater  and  higher-quality  connectivity  between  economies)  and  2 
(expanded global and regional investment opportunities). The TA is also fully aligned with ADB 
Strategy 2030 operational priorities 2 (accelerating progress in gender equality); 3 (tackling 
climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental 
sustainability); 6 (strengthening governance and institutional capacity); and 7 (fostering regional 
cooperation and integration).4 Moreover, it is closely aligned with the CAREC Strategy 2030 and 
the CAREC Energy Strategy 2030, which are directly linked to the national strategies of the 11 
CAREC member countries. 5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  CAREC energy sector at an important crossroads. While the energy sector has done 
well in powering the countries during a challenging period of rapid growth, new dynamics on the 
global energy scene are rapidly changing the context in which CAREC countries will have to 
operate over the next decade. The shifting global dynamics that will influence the CAREC region’s 
energy markets include the competitiveness of renewable energy, the importance of scaling up 
private sector financing, the necessity of addressing climate change, ongoing price and supply 
volatility  of  hydrocarbons,  and  improved  political  relations  in the region  stimulating  greater 
cooperation  and  inclusiveness.  As  earlier  CAREC  energy  strategies  have  not  adequately 
addressed these areas, the TA intends to offer a set of solutions that will prepare and equip the 
CAREC region to stay at the forefront of change under these new regional and global conditions. 
The additional economic and social challenges posed by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
 
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2019. CAREC Energy Strategy 2030: Common Borders, Common Solutions, 
Common Energy Future. Manila. The CAREC Energy Strategy 2030 was endorsed by the CAREC Ministerial 
Conference in Tashkent on 14 November 2019. 
2  The TA will appear in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website early in the third quarter of 2020. 
3  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–
2024. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  ADB. 2017. CAREC Strategy 2030. Manila.

2 
pandemic will make it even more important to secure reliable energy supplies and reduce energy 
shortages and interruptions, especially to rural and urban populations, important social facilities 
such as hospitals and schools, and businesses. 
 
4.  Political will and readiness for regional cooperation at historic peak. For the first time, 
the CAREC region’s energy ministers adopted a joint long-term vision for the regional energy 
sector and committed to implementing the CAREC Energy Strategy 2030 by signing a historic 
Ministerial Declaration on 20 September 2019 in Tashkent. The principle of “Common Borders, 
Common Solutions, Common Energy Future,” including a detailed 10-year action plan, was 
adopted as the central theme to advance the regional energy sector through this decade. The TA 
outputs are directly in sync with the endorsed action plan. 
 
5.  Mutual  benefits  from  cross-border  energy  connectivity  better  recognized. 
Interconnectivity between CAREC countries has improved since 2016. Flows in the Central Asia 
Power System among Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan increased 
almost fivefold from 583 gigawatt-hours in 2016 to 2,659 gigawatt-hours in 2018. Despite this 
trend, national electricity grids and gas pipeline networks are still planned in relative isolation. 
Both electricity and gas grids in the region must become smart and incorporate market principles 
to incentivize a more integrated system that can operate more efficiently and help build flexibility 
of supply and resiliency for all countries. At the same time, trade needs to grow beyond traditional 
markets such as the countries covered by the Central Asia Power System and expand to South 
Asia, notably to Afghanistan and Pakistan. Being part of a larger electricity network and gas 
pipeline system will allow energy to be traded at competitive prices, enable diversification of 
energy  sources,  and  provide  more  reliable  service  to  consumers.  Thus,  creating  the  right 
conditions for regional actors to establish long-term regional network development plans is an 
area the TA will address in partnership with ongoing initiatives by other development partners, 
particularly the United States Agency for International Development. 
 
6.  Structural  reforms  key  for  energy  sector  financial  sustainability.  Traditional 
government control of electricity and gas companies in the CAREC region and the absence of 
competition have led to distorted energy prices, inefficient network operation, and deteriorating 
energy infrastructure. The energy sector’s deep-seated financial difficulties have resulted in large-
scale subsidies in many countries in the region. Fiscal support needed to maintain subsidies 
causes a substantial burden on economies, depleting public budgets. Sector reforms can break 
this cycle and establish more market-oriented structures that will generate income and restore 
financial health. Several CAREC countries resolved to move from state-owned systems to more 
liberalized market structures, and reforms are already underway in some of them. Yet, capacity 
in some member countries to implement such reforms remains low. Therefore, the TA intends to 
promote knowledge flows across CAREC countries and equip them with the necessary tools to 
formulate appropriate reforms. 
 
7.  Private sector financing essential to meet investment needs. ADB estimated the 
energy infrastructure investment needs of the CAREC region (excluding the People’s Republic of 
China) in 2020–2030 to be $400 billion.6 In 2020 about two-thirds of investments were public 
sector investments, yet this is only a quarter of the needed investment. Therefore, private 
investment is essential to bridge the widening investment gap. Creating the conditions to scale 
up  private  investment,  which  in  turn  will  help  diversify  exports,  create  jobs,  and  improve 
efficiencies and promote innovation, is one of the region’s most challenging and important 
concerns. Given the common challenge and the modest size of economies, a regional approach 
 
6  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia’s Infrastructure Needs. Manila.

3 
can help (i) promote mutual learning to share successful and less successful project stories; and 
(ii) in selected cases, attract cost-competitive private investments by aggregating similar projects 
across countries in high-technology areas. 
 
8.  Strong economic and social imperatives of mainstreaming energy efficiency and 
higher share of renewables. The region has some of the most energy-intensive economies. 
Despite abundant renewable energy potential, installed solar and wind energy capacity amounted 
to less than 1% of the total capacity in 2019. Renewable energy and energy efficiency measures, 
while capital-intensive, have shorter payback periods than conventional sources, making these 
investment options particularly suited to attracting private sector financing. Furthermore, leading 
financial institutions and large wealth funds in the region are highly interested in impact financing, 
which  provides  adequate  returns  on  socially  and  environmentally  responsible  projects. 
International financial institutions also have a strong commitment to expand climate financing. 
Thus, there is a need to develop a robust pipeline of bankable energy efficiency and renewable 
energy  projects,  and  link  them  to  a  new regional  financing mechanism that  de-risks  such 
investments and provides a menu of investment options, such as debt, equity, guarantee, and 
leasing, leveraging ADB’s approaches and those of international financial institutions in other 
regions. 
 
9.  Developing human capital and inclusiveness key to a future-proofed energy sector. 
The work force of CAREC’s energy sector is relatively homogenous in terms of gender, age, and 
educational background. Women remain especially underrepresented, mirroring the global trend 
where women account for only about 20% of the global energy workforce7 and 11% of top global 
oil and gas executives.8 Hence, there is substantial room for opening up the energy industry to 
women and diversifying the sector’s workforce. A diverse and inclusive workforce has proved to 
multiply output and boost organizational performance. Companies and governments that increase 
their proportion of female employees have a more engaged and efficient staff, perform better, and 
maintain higher retention rates. Thus, the TA will promote gender equity in CAREC’s energy 
sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: energy security and regional connectivity 
among CAREC countries increased.9 The TA will have the following outcome: improved regional 
collaboration, scaled-up investments, and higher sustainability and inclusiveness in CAREC’s 
energy sector achieved.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Concept for the establishment of regional transmission cooperation 
association prepared. As the regional grid expands, increasing cooperation among transmission 
system operators and appropriate regional governance structures are needed not only to maintain 
physical infrastructure, but also to decide on future-oriented questions such as regional electricity 
and gas grid expansion, data sharing, and grid operation. While institutional structures such as 
 
7  Clean Energy Ministerial. Equal by 30: Gender Equality in the Clean Energy Sector. Paris. 
8  EY. 2019. How Diversity Boosts Performance in Oil and Gas.  
9  ADB. 2019 CAREC Energy Strategy 2030. Manila. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
the Coordinating Dispatch Center Energiya exist, they have a limited, strictly technical mandate 
that does not include regional strategic planning for a forward-looking, expanded smart system 
based on renewable energy. The proposed Central Asia transmission cooperation association will 
complement the  structures  in  place  and  particularly  focus  on  network  expansion  planning, 
elevating purely domestic planning efforts to a regional level by building a participatory process 
to jointly identify new projects of common interest and develop region-wide rules and standards 
for operating the grid. This governance structure will be key to increase regional connectivity, 
transparency, and trust, fostering expanded trade. 
 
12.  Output 2: CAREC energy reform atlas developed and private investors attracted. 
Given the uneven reform progress across countries in the region in the electricity and gas sectors, 
the TA will conceptualize a CAREC energy reform atlas and make it accessible to CAREC 
members through an interactive and user-friendly online tool. The atlas will comprise practical 
handbooks and advice on issues such as tariff reform; unbundling of generation, transmission, 
and distribution functions; and the protection of vulnerable customers. In addition, the TA will 
organize two international energy investment forums to attract new investors to the region and 
foster regional business-to-business contacts to stimulate private investment. Previous energy 
investment  forums  showcased  several  successful  ADB-supported  private  sector  projects, 
including in conflict zones and other high-risk environments, demonstrating the added value and 
benefits of support for private sector operations in the region. The TA will also help develop a 
CAREC energy outlook and investment report to provide investors with comprehensive data on 
demand and supply trends, and market outlook and dynamics to provide more transparency and 
help them make better investment decisions. 
 
13.  Output 3: Financing vehicle for green energy projects developed and consumer 
awareness of energy efficiency strengthened. In view of the low share of renewable energy 
and  levels energy efficiency in the CAREC region, the TA intends to create favorable conditions 
for the greening of the regional energy system. It will focus particularly on developing access to 
new financing vehicles for capital-intensive green energy projects and finding ways to raise 
awareness of energy efficiency among consumers. The TA will conceptualize a joint platform—
the CAREC green energy alliance—to convene project developers and potential financiers to 
identify and attract sources of funding for a pipeline of well-developed and investment-ready green 
energy projects. The long-term aim of the alliance should be to create a shared regional fund 
accessible to all CAREC members that will provide them with end-to-end solutions for cofinancing 
investments in clean energy projects. In addition, the TA intends to tap the huge potential for 
energy efficiency in the region, especially through well-designed and -targeted awareness-raising 
and information campaigns for consumers with support from the region’s mass media. 
 
14.  Output 4: CAREC women in energy program established. Given the low share of 
women employed in the regional energy sector, the TA will establish the first women in energy 
program in the CAREC region. The aim is to provide women with the necessary tools to build and 
boost their careers, join existing international networks, and become more visible in the regional 
energy sector. Major flagship events, such as the CAREC Energy Investment Forum, will lead by 
example by inviting women to make up at least 50% of speakers and panelists. To further raise 
the visibility of women in the regional energy sector, the TA will organize a CAREC women in 
energy summit in 2022. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.5 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation

5 
and Integration Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA through the Energy Division of the Central and West Asia 
Department and in close coordination with the resident missions of the CAREC member countries, 
the  Sustainable  Infrastructure  Division  of  the  East  Asia  Department,  and  the  Regional 
Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division of the Central and West Asia Department. 
CAREC’s Energy Sector Coordinating Committee, which is an official body forming part of the 
institutional setup of the CAREC Program composed of government officials from the member 
countries’ energy sectors, will discuss, contribute to, and endorse the products of the TA. The 
Energy Sector Coordinating Committee, the subworking group, and the task force will meet 
regularly, with support from the TA, to ensure full regional ownership. The TA will be implemented 
over 24 months (July 2020–June 2022). ADB will recruit individual international lead consultants 
for each TA output, supplemented by national consultants where needed. ADB will engage 
consulting firms for complex products such as the preparation of the CAREC energy outlook and 
investment report—a major product under output 2. ADB will engage another consulting firm to 
support the organization of three flagship conferences—two energy investment forums and a 
women in energy summit—and other regional meetings. An international coordinator and a 
national coordinator will support communication with the CAREC member countries and regional 
stakeholders, and provide further logistical support to members. A web and graphic designer will 
carry out other tasks, such as the development of a virtual tool kit for the CAREC energy reform 
atlas (output 2), and ADB will engage a producer to realize the  planned radio and/or TV 
commercials to promote awareness of energy efficiency via the local mass media (output 3). ADB 
will engage translators to provide simultaneous interpretation during the flagship conferences and 
other meetings and written English–Russian translations of the TA products.

6 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.11 
 
19.  Cofinancier requirements. The cofinancing requirements of the United Kingdom Fund 
for  Asia  Regional  Trade  and  Connectivity  under the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility include (i) submission of semiannual progress reports on project 
implementation to the trust fund team; (ii) notification to the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Thematic Group and the Partner Funds Division of ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate 
Change Department of major and minor changes in the project scope, duration, or funding 
arrangement;  and  (iii)  visibility  of  funding  from  the  Government  of  the  United  Kingdom  in 
publications and activities financed by the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade 
and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility 
for Fostering Expanded Regional Electricity and Gas Interconnection and Trade under the 
CAREC Energy Strategy 2030, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 1  9 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Concept for the establishment of regional transmission cooperation association prepared 
1.1 Contact transmission companies to inform them about the works to be launched (Q4 2020). 
1.2 Develop draft concept for CATCA (Q1 2021). 
1.3 Discuss and finalize draft concept with transmission companies (Q2 2021). 
1.4 Develop road map for the establishment of CATCA (Q3 2021). 
2.  CAREC energy reform atlas developed and private investors attracted 
2.1 Design CAREC energy web platform (Q3‒Q4 2020). 
2.2 Develop structure and content for CAREC energy reform atlas and go live (Q2 2021‒Q1 2022). 
2.3 Develop CAREC energy outlook and investment report (Q4 2020–Q1 2022). 
2.4 Organize the fifth and sixth energy investment forums (Q1 2021 and Q1 2022). 
3.   Financing vehicle for green energy projects developed and consumer awareness of energy 
efficiency strengthened 
3.1 Develop energy efficiency leaflets (Q2 2021). 
3.2 Produce energy efficiency radio and/or TV commercials (Q3 2021). 
3.3 Develop concept for CAREC green energy alliance (Q4 2021). 
4.   CAREC women in energy program established 
4.1 Convene task force on women’s empowerment (Q1 2021). 
4.2 Develop concept and work program for women in energy program (Q3 2021). 
4.3 Launch women in energy program live on CAREC energy web platform (Q4 2021). 
4.4 Organize CAREC women in energy summit (Q2 2022).

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE
